intro: Diporidium cordatum, commonly known as the heartleaf ptelea, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its heart-shaped leaves, which are typically opposite and have a smooth or slightly hairy surface. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are clustered in terminal umbels, and it is often found in moist, wooded areas. Its botanical features make it a distinctive member of the Rhamnaceae family. The plant is also noted for its aromatic foliage and has been used in traditional herbal medicine.
